utterance: Go to de blue flag! Go to de red an' yalleh! Go to de white cross! Go to de check flag! Go to de blue anchor! Go to de check an' green!

utterance: This man is not a Congo.
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: He is a Jaloff. See his fine, straight nose; moreover, he is a prince. If I whip him he will die.
speaker: the overseer

utterance: Get an interpreter. and come to an understand. ing. I shall require it of you.
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: Ah, Clemence, we want you—for an inter- preter!
speaker: the overseer

utterance: I cannot, I cannot! Get Miché Agricole Fusilier. He can interpret any and everything!
speaker: Clemence

utterance: Agricola Fusilier! The last man on earth to make peace.
speaker: the overseer

utterance: I, Agricola Fusilier, stand as an interpreter to a negro? H-sir!
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: But I thought you might know of some person.
speaker: the overseer

utterance: Ah! if I did not-who would? You may take Palmyre.
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: Yes, take Palmyre; she has picked up as many negro dialects as I know European languages.
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: As Señor will remember I told him; how can a man expect to plough with a zebra?
speaker: the overseer

utterance: Stop! She lies, he does not decline the honor! Let me take the man to Agricola !
speaker: the overseer

utterance: No! I will tell. He will take the place and fill it if you will give me to him for his wife-but oh, gentlemen, for the love of God-I do not want to be his wife!

addressee: Don José Martinez and the overseer

utterance: I leave it entirely with Señor Fusilier.
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: But he is not my master; he has no right to give me to anyone.
speaker: Palmyre

utterance: Silence!
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: It was royal!
speaker: the overseer

utterance: I go to Agricola Fusilier to see my be- trothed.
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: Trouble coming; better not deceive that fellow.
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "Bras-Coupé dares not look upon a spirit."
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "No tricks, girl!"
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: "We have made a sad discovery, Miché Fusilier,"
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "Bras-Coupé is here; we have him in a room just yonder. But-the truth is, sir, Bras-Coupé is a voudou."
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "'Well, and suppose he is; what of it? Only hush; do not let his master know it. It is nothing; all the blacks are voudous, more or less."
speaker: Miché Fusilier

utterance: "But he declines to dress himself - has painted himself all rings and stripes, antelope-fashion."
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "Tell him Agricola Fusilier says, 'dress immediately!'"
speaker: Miché Fusilier

utterance: "'Oh, Miché, we have said that five times already, and his answer-you will pardon me- his answer is-spitting on the ground-that you are a contemptible white trash."
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "He is looking for Palmyre,"
speaker: some

utterance: "On the mountain chain, my friends, I've been cutting cane, my friends, Money for to gain, my friends, For to give Palmyre. Ah! Palmyre, Palmyre, my love, my true, I love you, dear—I love, I love, love you.'"
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "Mountain?"
speaker: one slave

utterance: "What's a mountain? We haven't such things in Louisiana.”
speaker: one slave

utterance: "But there are mountains a-plenty in Africa; listen!'"
speaker: another

utterance: "Ah! Palmyre, my little bird, Palmyre, I love you, love; I love you, love you, dear."

utterance: "Bravissimo!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Bras-Coupé !"

utterance: "'Bras-Coupé must wait till I give him his wife."
speaker: Palmyre's mistress

utterance: "'Bras-Coupé hears the voice of zombis; the voice is sweet, but the words are very strong; from the same sugar-cane comes molasses and rum; Bras-Coupé says to zombis, 'Bras- Coupé will wait; but if the white trash deceive Bras-Coupé-"
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "Bras-Coupé will call the great god of the Voudous!'"
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "More!'"
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "We are bewitched!'"

utterance: "we are bewitched!'"
speaker: two or three ladies

utterance: "Look to your wives and daughters!'"

utterance: "Shoot the black devils without mercy!'"
speaker: another

utterance: "She loves her prince,'"
speaker: the negroes

utterance: "'Simple creatures!'"
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "she loves nothing; she hates Agricola; it's a case of hate at first sight-the strongest kind.'"
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "It is that accursed alligator, Bras-Coupé, down yonder in the swamp."
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "Alas!'"
speaker: the planters

utterance: "we are all poor men!'"
speaker: the planters

utterance: "He does not understand planting,'"
speaker: his neighbors

utterance: "neither does his overseer. Maybe, too, it is true, as he says, that he is voudoued.'"
speaker: his neighbors

utterance: "Bras-Coupé wants his wife!'"
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "Bras-Coupé wants his wife!'"
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "Seize him!'"
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: "Speak to him,'"
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: "May this house and all in it who are not women be accursed."
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "May its fields not know the plough nor nourish the cattle that overrun it."
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "Bras-Coupé wants his wife,"
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "You shall not have her!'"
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: "May weeds cover the ground until the air is full of their odor and the wild beasts of the forest come and lie down under their cover."
speaker: Bras-Coupé

utterance: "Why, in the name of St. Francis,'"
speaker: the priest

utterance: "didn't the Señora use her power over the black scoundrel when he stood and cursed that day?'"
speaker: the priest

utterance: "Why, to tell you the truth, father,'"
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "I can only suppose she thought Bras-Coupé had half a right to do it.”
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "Ah, ah, I see; like her brother, Honoré- looks at both sides of a question—a miserable practice; but why couldn't Palmyre use her eyes? They would have stopped him.'"
speaker: the priest

utterance: "Palmyre? Why Palmyre has become the best monture (Plutonian medium) in the parish. Agricola Fusilier himself is afraid of her. Sir, I think sometimes Bras-Coupé is dead and his spirit has gone into Palmyre. She would rather add to his curse than take from it.'"
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "whipping would help her case; the whip is a great sanctifier. I fancy it would even make a Christian of Bras-Coupé.'"
speaker: the priest

utterance: "And if we,'"
speaker: the newsbearer

utterance: "get the juice of the sugar-cane to crystallize, we shall yet save our lands and homes. Oh, Señor, it will make you strong again to see these fields all cane and the long rows of negroes and negresses cutting it, while they sing that song by which they count the canes they cut,'"
speaker: the newsbearer

utterance: "And Honoré Grandissime is going to introduce it on his lands,'"
speaker: the newsbearer

utterance: "That is true,'"
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: "I have some good tidings, too,'"
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: "my beloved lady has borne me a son.'"
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: "Another scion of the house of Grand- I mean Martinez!'"
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: "And now, Don José, let me say that I have an item of rare intelligence!'"
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: "he is not exactly taken yet, but they are on his track.'"
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: "Who?'"
speaker: Don José Martinez

utterance: "The police. We may say Bras-Coupé is virtually in our grasp.'"
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: "Besides, there is Article 27 of the same code: The slave who, having struck his master, shall have produced a bruise, shall suffer capital punishment'-a very necessary law!'"
speaker: Agricola Fusilier

utterance: "the runaway slave who shall continue to be so for one month from the day of his being denounced to the officers of justice, shall have his ears cut off and shall be branded with the flower-de-luce on the shoulder; and on a second offence of the same nature, persisted in during one month of his being denounced, he shall be hamstrung, and be marked with the flower-de-luce on the other shoulder. On the third offence, he shall die.'"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "You cannot put that creature in there. He would suf- focate under a roof-he has been too long out-of-doors for that. Put him on my cottage porch."
speaker: the overseer

utterance: "Bras-Coupé, the master is dead; he is just buried. As he was dying, Bras- Coupé, he asked that you would forgive him."
speaker: Palmyre

utterance: "Is your mistress well enough by this time to venture here? Let her come. Tell her not to fear, but to bring the babe-in her own arms, tell her quickly!"

utterance: "The poor devil! Palmyre, you must get the priest."

utterance: "We shall fill that ditch,"

utterance: "You speak French?"

utterance: "I would rather talk English, if you can do so,"
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "My name, Jean Poquelin."
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "How can I serve you, Mr. Poquelin?"
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "My house is yondeh in swamp."
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "Dat swamp billong to me."
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "Yes, sir."
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "To me; Jean Poquelin; I h-own him me- self."
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "Well, sir?"
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "He don't billong to you; I get him from my father."
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "That is perfectly true, Mr. Poquelin, as far as I am aware."
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "You want to make street pass yondeh?"
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "I do not know, sir; it is quite probable; but the city will repay you for any loss you may suffer-you will get paid, you under- stand."
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "Street can't pass dare."
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "You will have to see the city authorities about that, Mr. Poquelin."
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "Pardon, you is not the Governor? Ah, yes. You har the Governor - yes. Veh-well. I come to you. I tell you, street can't pass at my 'ouse. But you will have to see I come to you. You har the Governor. I know not the new laws. I ham a Fr-r-rench-a- man! Fr-rench-a-man have something go contrarie-he come at his Governor. I come at you. If me not had been bought from my king like black man in the hold time, ze King of France would-a-show to take care his men to make street in right places. But, I know; we billong to that President. I want you do somesin for me, eh?"
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "What is it?"
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "I want you tell that President, street— can't-pass-at-my-'ouse."
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "Have a chair, Mr. Poquelin,"
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "Mr. Poquelin, tell me, is it your house that our Creole citizens tell such odd stories about?"
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "You don't see me trade some Guinea nigga? You don't see me make some smugglin'? But, I am Jean Marie Poquelin. I mind my hown bizniss. Dat all right? Adieu."
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "He say', he come, to make you the fair warning how you muz not make the street pass at his 'ouse."
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "such impudence was refreshing"
speaker: the officer

utterance: "He say': 'Why you don't want?'"
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "He say', that marsh is a too unhealthy for peopl' to live."
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "But we expect to drain his old marsh; it's not going to be a marsh."
speaker: the officer

utterance: "He say' the canal is private canal,"
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "Oh! that old ditch; that's to be filled up. Tell the old man we're going to fix him up nicely."
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "Tell him, by the time we finish, there'll not be a ghost left in his shanty."
speaker: the Governor

utterance: "I know, I know,"
speaker: Jean Poquelin

utterance: "'Why, it will make his old place worth ten dol- lars to one,"
speaker: the official

utterance: "'Tis not for de worse of de property,"
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "'I should guess not, seems to me as if some of these old Creoles would rather live in a craw- fish hole than to have a neighbor."
speaker: the official

utterance: "You know what make old Jean Poque- lin make like that? I will tell you. You know-"
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "He is a witch."
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "Ho, ho, ho!"
speaker: the official

utterance: "You don't believe it? What you want to bet? What you want to bet?"
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "How do you know?"
speaker: the official

utterance: "Dass what I goin' to tell you. You know, one evening, I was shooting some cranes. I killed three; but I had trouble to fine them, it was becoming so dark. When I have them I start' to come home; then I got to pass at Jean Poquelin's house."
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "Ho, ho, ho!"
speaker: the official

utterance: "Wait. I come along slow, not making some noises; still, still".
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "And scared,"
speaker: the official

utterance: "But, wait. I get all past the house. 'Ah!' I say; 'all right!' Then I see two thing' be- fore! Hah! I get as cold and humide, and shake like a leaf. You think it was nothing? There I see, so plain as can be (though it was making nearly dark), I see Jean-Marie-Po- que-lin walkin' right in front, and right there beside of him was something like a man-but not a man-white like paint!-I dropp' on the grass from scared- they pass'; so sure as I live 'twas the ghost of Jacques Poquelin, his brother!"
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "Pooh!"
speaker: the listener

utterance: "I'll put my han' in the fire,"
speaker: interpreter

utterance: "But did you never think, that that might be Jack Poquelin, as you call him, alive and well, and, for some cause, hid away by his brother ?"
speaker: the other

utterance: "But there are no cause!"
speaker: the other

utterance: "The old tyrant!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "You don't mean an old tyrant?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Well, then, why doesn't he build when the public need demands it? What does he live in that unneighborly way for?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "The old pirate!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "The old kidnapper!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "There he goes, with the boys after him! Ah! ha ha! Jean-ah Po- quelin! Ah! Jean-ah! Aha! aha! Jean-ah Marie! Jean-ah Poquelin! The old villain!"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "The old fraud, pretends to live in a haunted house, does he? We'll tar and feather him some day. Guess we can fix him."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Go up, thou bald-head,"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "As long as that house stands we shall have bad luck. Do you not see our peas and beans dying, our cabbages and lettuce going to seed and our gardens turning to dust, while every day you can see it raining in the woods? The rain will never pass old Poquelin's house. He keeps a charm to conjure with. He has conjured the whole suburb Sainte Marie. And why, the old wretch? Simply because our playful and in- nocent children call after him as he passes."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Fact is, gentlemen, it would take us at least twelve months to make Mr. Pokaleen understand the rather original features of our system, and he wouldn't subscribe when we'd done; besides, the only way to see him is to stop him on the street."
speaker: the President

utterance: "Better meet a bear robbed of her whelps,"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "You're mistaken as to that. I did meet him, and stopped him, and found him quite polite. But I could get no satisfaction from him; the fellow wouldn't talk in French, and when I spoke in English he hoisted his old shoulders up, and gave the same answer to everything I said."
speaker: the President

utterance: "And what was that?"
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "That it 'don't worse w'ile?'"
speaker: the President

utterance: "Oh! it isn't worth while, eh? Well, we think it is."
speaker: unspecified

utterance: "Mr. President, this market-house project, as I take it, is not alto- gether a selfish one; the community is to be benefited by it. We may feel that we are working in the public interest, if we employ all possible means to oust this old nuisance from among us. You may know that at the time the street was cut through, this old Poquelann did all he could to prevent it. It was owing to a certain connection which I had with that affair that I heard a ghost story, which, of course, I am not going to relate; but I may say that my profound conviction, arising from a prolonged study of that story, is, that this old villain, John Poquelann, has his brother locked up in that old house. Now, if this is so, and we can fix it on him, I merely suggest that we can make the matter highly useful. I don't know, but that it is an action we owe to the community— hem!"
speaker: a Director

utterance: "How do you propose to handle the sub- ject?"
speaker: the President

utterance: "I was thinking, that, as a Board of Directors, it would be unadvisable for us to authorize any action involving tres- pass; but if you, for instance, Mr. President, should, as it were, for mere curiosity, request some on
speaker: a Director

utterance: "I tell you frankly," "I go into this purely for reasons of my own."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "It is not a ghost," "I know it cannot be a ghost;"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "It is a living man,"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Now, if I dare venture, the mystery is solved."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Great Heaven! can it be that the dead do walk?"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Oh, oh! I see, I understand!"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "I can't help it, gentlemen; I can't help you to make a case against the old man, and I'm not going to."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "We did not expect this disappointment, Mr. White."
speaker: unnamed

utterance: "I can't help that, sir. No, sir; you had better not appoint any more investigations. Somebody'll investigate himself into trouble. No, sir; it isn't a threat, it is only my advice, but I warn you that whoever takes the task in hand will rue it to his dying day-which may be hastened, too."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "surprised."
speaker: the President

utterance: "I don't care a rush," "I don't care a rush if you are, sir. No, my nerves are not disordered; my head's as clear as a bell. No, I'm not excited."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Well, sir, if you want to know the fact, I have; and if you choose to cultivate old Poquelin's society you can have one, too."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "White,"
speaker: unnamed

utterance: "White,"
speaker: unnamed

utterance: "What?"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Did you see the ghost?"
speaker: unnamed

utterance: "Yes, sir; I did,"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Was it white?" "No-yes-nearly so we can't tell-but we saw it."
speaker: madcap boys

utterance: "If that old rascal lived in the country we come from," "he'd have been tarred and feathered before now, wouldn't he, Sanders?"
speaker: certain Américains

utterance: "Well, now, he just would."
speaker: Sanders

utterance: "And we'd have rid him on a rail, wouldn't we?"
speaker: certain Américains

utterance: "That's what I allow."
speaker: Sanders

utterance: "Tell you what you could do." "What is it you call this thing where an old man marries a young girl, and you come out with horns and "
speaker: certain Américains

utterance: "Charivari?"
speaker: Creoles

utterance: "Yes, that's it. Why don't you shivaree him?"
speaker: certain Américains

utterance: "And you say," "the old black mute has been going by here alone? Patty, suppose old Poquelin should be cooking up some mischief; he doesn't lack cause; the way that clod hit him the other day was enough to have killed him. Why, Patty, he dropped as quick as that! No wonder you haven't seen him. I wonder if they haven't heard something about him up at the drug-store. Suppose I go and see."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Do,"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "That moon is ghost enough for one house,"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "Patty," "the drug-clerk says the boys are going to shivaree old Poquelin to-night. I'm going to try to stop it."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "'Why, White," "you'd better not. You'll get hurt."
speaker: Patty

utterance: "No, I'll not."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Yes, you will."
speaker: Patty

utterance: "I'm going to sit out here until they come along. They're compelled to pass right by here."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "'Why, White, it may be midnight before they start; you're not going to sit out here till then."
speaker: Patty

utterance: "Yes, I am."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Well, you're very foolish,"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "What's that?"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "That's the nine-o'clock gun,"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Patty, you'd better go in and go to bed,"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "I'm not sleepy."
speaker: Patty

utterance: "Well, you're very foolish,"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Patty, suppose I walk out to the old house and see if I can find out anything."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Suppose," " you don't do any such -listen!"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "They are coming this way,"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "You had better go into the house, Patty."

utterance: "So had you."
speaker: Patty

utterance: "No. I'm going to see if I can't stop them."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "'Why, White!'"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "I'll be back in a minute,"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Stop these fellows, Bienvenu, stop them just a minute, till I tell them something."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Bienvenu," "don't shivaree old Poquelin to-night; he's"-
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "My friend," "who tell you I goin' to charivari somebody, eh? You suppose because I make a little playful on this tin pan that I am drunk?"
speaker: Bienvenu

utterance: "Oh, no, Bienvenu, old fellow, you're all right. I was afraid you might not know that old Poquelin was sick, you know; but you're not going there, are you?"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "My friend, I am very sorree to tell you that you are so drunk like a fool. I am ashame' of you. I am the servant of the public. These citizen' are going to ask Jean Poquelin to give to the Ursuline' at the hospital two hondred fifty dolla'"
speaker: Bienvenu

utterance: "Hey, what?" "Five hondred dolla', yes!"
speaker: a listener

utterance: "Yes," "and if he riffuse we make him some little music; ta-ra-ta!"
speaker: Bienvenu

utterance: "Old Poquelin got no bizniz drink s'much whiskey."
speaker: Bienvenu

utterance: "But, gentlemen," "the old man is very sick."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "My faith!" "we did not make him to be sick. W'en we have say we going make the charivari, do you want that we all tell a lie? My faith!"
speaker: a tiny Creole

utterance: "But you can shivaree somebody else,"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Yes!" "and charivari Jean-ah Poquelin to-morrow!"
speaker: Bienvenu

utterance: "Let us go to Madame Schneider!"

utterance: "One hondred dolla' for the Charity Hospital!"

utterance: "Hurrah!"
speaker: unnamed

utterance: "One hondred dolla' for Charity Hospital!"
speaker: unnamed

utterance: "Hurrah!"
speaker: unnamed

utterance: "Well, if it isn't away after midnight."

utterance: "Is that you, White?"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "Yes."

utterance: "I succeeded, Patty."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Did you?"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "Yes. They've gone down to shivaree the old Dutchwoman who married her step-daughter's sweetheart. They say she has got to pay a hundred dollars to the hospital before they stop."
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "What time?"
speaker: Patty

utterance: "Half-past three. Patty, I haven't slept a wink. Those fellows are out yet. Don't you hear them?"
speaker: the little Secretary

utterance: "Why, White, they're coming this way!"
speaker: Patty

They can afford to fear dogs," he replied,

utterance:
In short," said I, closing the book, "those
imaginative victories of soul over circumstance
become essentially ours by sympathy and emu-
lation, don't they?
speaker: Smith

utterance:
O yes," he sighed, and added an indistinct
word about "spasms of virtue.
speaker: A man

utterance:
You think," interrupted Gregory, "there's
a fresh chance for me.
speaker: A man

utterance:
For all the common run of us!" I cried.
Why not? And even if there isn't, hasn't it a
beauty and a value? Isn't a rose a rose, on the
bush or off? Gold is gold wherever you find
it, and the veriest spasm of true virtue, coined
into action, is true virtue and counts. It may
not work my nature's whole redemption, but it
works that way, and is just so much solid help
toward the whole world's uplift.
speaker: Smith

utterance:
I'm glad it's not," he said, "for I reckon my
ruling motive is always fear.
speaker: A man

utterance: Was it fear this evening?
speaker: Smith

utterance:
Yes," he replied, "it was. It was fear of a
coward's name, and a sort of abject horror of
being one.
speaker: A man

utterance:
Too big a coward inside," I laughed, "to
be a big, stout coward outside," and he as-
sented.
speaker: Smith

utterance:
Smith," he said, and paused long, "if I
were a hard drinker and should try to quit, it
wouldn't be courage that would carry me
through, but fear; quaking fear of a drunkard's
life and a drunkard's death.
speaker: A man

utterance:
I'm afraid so," he responded. "I had a
strange experience once," he presently added,
as if reminded of it by what we had last said.
"I took a prisoner.
speaker: A man

utterance: By the overwhelming power of fear?
speaker: Smith

utterance:
Partly, yes. I saw him before he saw me
and I felt that if I didn't take him he'd either
take me or shoot me, so I covered him and he
surrendered. We were in an old pine clearing
grown up with oak bushes.
speaker: A man

utterance:
Would it have been less strange," I in-
quired, "if you had been in an old oak clearing
grown up with pine bushes?
speaker: Smith

utterance: No, he'd have got away just the same.
speaker: A man

utterance: What! you didn't bring him in ?
speaker: Smith

utterance:
Only part of the way. Then he broke and
ran.
speaker: A man

utterance: And you had to shoot him?
speaker: Smith

utterance:
No. I didn't even shoot at him. I couldn't,
Smith; he looked so much like me. It was like
seeing my own ghost. All the time I had him
something kept saying to me, 'You're your
own prisoner - you're your own prisoner.'
And do you know-that thing comes back to
me now every time I get into the least sort of
a tight place?
speaker: A man

utterance: I wish it would come to me," I responded.
speaker: Smith

utterance:
My schooner's
sold for debt! You know the reason; I've
seen you read it all over me every time we
have met, these twelve months-O don't look
at me!
speaker: A man

utterance:
Yes," he bab-
bled on, "it's a fixed fact, Smith; the cracked
fiddle's a smashed fiddle at last!
speaker: A man

utterance:
I've finished all the easy parts
-the first ecstasies of pure license-the long
down-hill plunge, with all its mad exhilara-
tions-the wild vanity of venturing-that big-
ness of the soul's experiences which makes
even its anguish seem finer than the old bit-
terness of tame propriety-I've gone through
all those things; they are all behind me, now
-the valley of horrors is before! You can't
understand it, Smith. O you can't under-
stand it!
speaker: A man

utterance:
Gregory, that day
the dogs jumped on you-you remember?-
didn't you say if ever you should reach this
condition your fear might save you?
speaker: Smith

utterance:
Do you "-a
ray of humor lighted his eyes-" do you still
believe in spasms of virtue?
speaker: A man

utterance:
Thank heaven, yes!" laughed I, and he
said good-by and was gone.
speaker: Smith

Don't look for me.
You can't find me. I'm
not going to kill or hurt myself, and I'll report

speaker: A man

utterance: No! O no! call it anything but courage! I felt I felt as though I were a murderer. All I knew was that it had to be done. I trembled like a thief. I had to stoop twice before I could take up the axe, and I was so cold my teeth chattered. When I lifted the first blow I didn't know where it was going to fall. But it struck as true as a die, and then I flew at it. I never chopped so fast or clean in my life. I wasn't fierce; I was as full of self-delight as an overpraised child. And yet when something delayed me an instant, I found I was still shaking. Courage
speaker: A man

utterance: O no; I know what it was, and I knew then. But I had no choice; it was my last chance.

utterance: Maybe so, but I wasn't; it was the one sane thing I could do;

utterance: There wasn't anything else to do. The feelings came later, too, in an easy sort o' gradual way. I never could quite make out how men get such clear notions of what they call Providence,' but, just the same, I know by experience there's all the difference of peace and misery, or life and death, whether you're in partnership with the things that help the world on, or with those that hold it back.
speaker: A man

utterance: did not your longing for our human world continue?
speaker: wife

utterance: No, but I got a new liking for it-although, you understand, I never had anything against it, of course. It's too big and strong for me, that's all; and that's my fault. Your man on that slippery roof, kicking his shoes off, is a sort of parable to me. If your hand or your foot offend you and you have to cut it off, that's a physical disablement, and bad enough. But when your gloves and your shoes are too much for you, and you have to pluck them off and cast them from you, you find each one is a great big piece of the civilized world, and you hardly know how much you did like it, till you've lost it. And still, it's no use longing, when you know your limitations, and I saw I'd got to keep my world trimmed down to where I could run barefooted on the sand.
speaker: A man

utterance: You might not think it, but the best was a Bible I'd chanced to carry along;
speaker: A man

utterance: just one of these ordinary Bibles you see lying around in people's houses.

utterance: Then there was one, beginning, 'Lord, my heart is not haughty, nor mine eyes lofty; neither do I exercise myself in great matters, or in things too wonderful for me;' and by and by, it says, 'Surely, I have quieted myself as a child that is weaned: my soul is even as a weaned child.'

utterance: Why it's always Sunday there. Here almost everybody feels duty bound to work harder than somebody else, or else make somebody else work harder than he, and you need a day every now and then for Sunday or Sabbath, at least. Oh, I sup- pose it's all one in the end, isn't it? You take your's in a pill, I take mine in a powder. Not that it's the least bit like a dose, however, ex- cept for the good it does.

utterance: Behind all these facts and incidents, I was deeply stirred to make a story of them by the very natural re- volt of feeling I experienced about this time in becoming acquainted with the harsher pro- visions of the old Black Code of Louisiana.

speaker: One of his literary friends

utterance: DEAR LADIES AND SIR:-It gives me great pleasure to write to you, and I make haste to thank Miss Louise and Miss Mary for their gracefully written and really eloquent letters to me. When I hear that you are enjoying the pleasures of the sea-side, I am so delighted that I open my sleeve slyly and laugh right into it till it is as full of laugh as a bath-house. I have a hole in the elbow for this very purpose. A man named Pauvreté (Poverty), a Frenchman, made it for me for nothing. Some of these days I hope to come and take tea with you in your tea-set; that is if it lasts long enough. But if not I suppose we can have a new tea-set made; they make them in Germany. I'll try and have the money to pay for them. I must tell you that I have bought a big doll for myself. It is only a head, to be sure, but it is as big as a water- melon and is named Cicero. You'll see it when we all get home. God speed the day.
speaker: G. W. Cable
addressee: MISSES LOUISE AND MARY AND MASTER GEORGE B. Cable

utterance: MY DEAR LITTLE DAUGHTER :-I must send you a line for your own dear self. I am anxious to hear from you as well as from sweet mother, and I hope I may get a word or two from your own hand. I could not in a whole hour tell you all the things I have seen since we parted. But I can say that all the time I saw the beauties of land or sea or hill or valley, whether nature's work or man's, I was still thinking of my beloved ones far away on the mountains. Yet I did not fret, for I know that the Good Shepherd keeps my little flock, and my prayer is that their souls may be precious in His sight. I pray that they may be sweet, gentle, obedient children, trying to do their parents' will before the parents have to express it. Be careful to help each other. Be amiable each to each. Remember in everything you do you are serving God. Do everything cheerfully-gladly. Tell Mary not to tease and to keep her face at least half clean. Tell Lucy I wish I had her here now with a little salt and pepper and mustard. I would eat her for dinner. Tell Margaret not to forget her breakfast in the morn- ing, her dinner afterwards, nor her supper in the evening. Tell her not to be cross to Lucy and to mind mother as well as sister Louise. Now, form in procession and each kiss mother as you pass by. Here are four kisses for four sweet girls and four for their dear mother.
speaker: G. W. Cable

utterance: My Two DARLING LITTLE HONEY-BEES: I shall have to write to you both at once, as I believe I have not yet answered Louise's letter. It makes me very happy to have such good accounts of you, both from mother and Aunt Mary. You are my precious treasures. Everybody remembers, here, how nicely you took care of yourselves and of one another when you were in New York last year. I am pleased with the school-paper idea. Your circula- tion is small, I suppose, but select. The Century prints this month, 140,000 copies. I want each of you to kiss Margaret and Lucy for me. I will give you some items for your paper. Let me see : 1. Mr. Joseph Pennell, the noted artist and etcher, will leave America for Europe about the 1st of next Janu- ary, to make sketches of Italian architecture. 2. Oriental rugs are being imported to New York and freely sold. A fine eastern rug is more beautiful after it has been used for a hundred years than it was when it was new. Some are made of wool and some of silk. Kiss the dear, dear mother.
speaker: G. W. Cable

utterance: O friends whose hearts still hold their prime, Whose bright example warms and cheers, You teach us how to smile at Time And set to music all his years.

utterance: Let the tree speak for me in the coming years.
speaker: Mrs. Wynne

utterance: Intelligence and courtesy not always are combined, Often in a wooden house, a golden room we find.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: If you would find this golden room, take the train to Northampton, Mass., go up Elm Street, turn into Dryads' Green, house right-hand corner, enter, go up stairs and take the last door on the left. A golden room—a golden memory.
speaker: Mr. Barrie and MARY BARRIE

utterance: With some experience, but not as much as desired, to justify an opinion, we pronounce Mr. Cable the most de- lightful of visitors. Every day some new charm is found in him. He glides into the bosom of the family before we are aware, without effort, and becomes one of us. He carries an atmosphere with him which gently and insensibly envelops the household. But the greatest charm of all was revealed when he gave Skibo Castle inmates a reading, for which the large hall was admirably adapted. Altogether fine as the performance was, the most striking feature was this slender little delicate writer of books, revealing himself as an actor of great dramatic force. For an hour he held us all spellbound. There is, however, one serious fault with this wonderful man, his visits are too short; although this has another side. He could not stay very long before we should be- come so dependent upon his presence as to feel his absence too severely. Better not get too well acquainted with him.
speaker: Andrew Carnegie

utterance: Better lo'ed ye canna be, Will ye no come back again?
speaker: assembled household

utterance: DEAR MR. CABLE: In justice to your audience of this evening, we think you should be told that the people of the old Puritan town of Dare still under the grim influence of Salem witch- craft and persecution of Quakers. Laughter still seems to them a little immoral and applause something to be in- dulged in with extreme moderation. Could you have heard the comments of the occupants of that horse-car mentioned by you at the introduction of your story, you would have learned how deep an impression your reading had made. As for us, we are not D people, and we laughed, wept and applauded as we chose. No, we laughed and wept as you chose, and applauded as we chose. And now, we thank you for one of the great pleasures of our lives. We are not autograph hunters and so simply sign ourselves,
speaker: TWO OF THE AUDIENCE

utterance: DEAR S: I want that letter you wrote for my Christmas. Maybe you have destroyed it. If so, never mind, we are friends anyhow. And all the more are we friends because we don't generally get things done as quickly as some other people, very able and delightful people, too, can do them. My main purpose in writing this is to thank you for your intention, and to say that I regret your name was not in the list of those to whom I replied.
speaker: George W. Cable

utterance: You are so accustomed to his wit, that you take it as daily food and do not know that you are being fed on nectar and ambrosia.
speaker: a friend of his

utterance: Did ever anyone have such a father as ours?
